persona_description: Olivia is a 19-year-old student with a high school diploma living in suburban Chicago with a low income. She is single and uninsured, relying on free clinics for healthcare. Olivia is sedentary, smokes, and has untreated anxiety. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not taking prenatal vitamins.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Medical Research Interview - Session Start

Thank you so much for taking the time to meet with me today, Olivia. I really appreciate your willingness to participate in this research. 

Before we dive in, I want you to know that this is a safe, confidential space. There are no judgment calls here—I'm just trying to understand your experiences and what you're going through so we can better support young people like you.

Let me start with something foundational:

**How are you feeling today? And how are you doing with your pregnancy so far?**

I know this might be a lot to process, especially if this is new for you, so I want to start by just hearing where you're at emotionally and physically right now.

---

*[I'm settling in, maintaining an open, attentive posture, ready to listen and take notes as needed]*

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia shifts slightly in her seat, tucking her hair behind her ear. She seems a bit nervous but willing to talk]*

Um, yeah, okay. So... I'm 19. I graduated high school last year, but I'm not really in school right now. I'm kind of between things, I guess. Job-wise, I mean. I've done some part-time stuff here and there, but nothing steady, so money's pretty tight.

*[She glances down at her hands]*

I live with my parents in the suburbs here—northwest of Chicago. It's... it's okay, but there's a lot going on at home. My parents are supportive, but they're also stressed about bills and everything, so finding out I'm pregnant was... yeah. It was a lot.

*[She pauses, then continues more quietly]*

I'm single. The guy and I aren't together anymore. We weren't really serious, and when I told him, he kind of just... disappeared. So I'm dealing with this mostly on my own, which is scary.

*[She looks up briefly]*

I don't have health insurance. I've been going to the free clinic when I need something, but it's hard because you have to wait forever, and sometimes they're not open when I can get there. I smoke—I know I probably shouldn't, especially now—and I'm just... I'm not really sure what I'm doing, honestly. This whole pregnancy thing wasn't planned, and I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do.

*[She fidgets with her sleeve]*

Is that... is that what you needed to know?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia takes a deep breath and nods slowly]*

Yeah, um... so I found out maybe... I don't know, like 6 or 7 weeks ago? I missed my period, and at first I was like, "okay, maybe it's just late," but then I kept feeling weird. Nauseous, tired all the time, my boobs were sore. I was at a friend's house and she had a pregnancy test, so I just... I took it. And it was positive.

*[She wraps her arms around herself]*

I didn't tell anyone for like two weeks after that. I was just kind of in denial, I guess. I kept thinking maybe it was wrong, or maybe it would just go away on its own. But then I knew I had to tell someone, so I told my mom first. She cried, but not in like, a super angry way. More like... worried? My dad was quieter about it. They want to help, but they're also stressed because they're already struggling financially.

*[She looks down at her lap]*

I went to the free clinic after that to confirm it, and they did an ultrasound and told me I'm about 9 weeks now. So this is my first pregnancy—I've never been pregnant before. And honestly, I'm still kind of processing it all.

*[She hesitates]*

The clinic gave me some paperwork about prenatal vitamins and stuff, but I haven't really... I haven't started taking them yet. I know I probably should, but I've just been so overwhelmed and confused about what I even want to do. Like, I don't know if I'm keeping it, putting it up for adoption, or... 

*[Her voice trails off]*

I'm sorry, I know that probably sounds bad.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia shifts in her seat, her expression becoming a bit more animated as she recalls the experience]*

So like I said, I went to the free clinic probably... maybe 4 or 5 weeks after I found out? I was really nervous going in. I didn't know what to expect, and I was worried they'd judge me or something.

*[She picks at a thread on her sleeve]*

The wait was really long. I got there early in the morning, and I didn't see anyone until like two hours later. But when I finally got called back, the nurse was actually really nice. She didn't make me feel bad or anything. She asked me a bunch of questions about my health history, when my last period was, all that stuff.

*[She pauses, remembering]*

The ultrasound was... weird but also kind of cool? Like, seeing the baby on the screen. That made it feel more real, you know? The technician didn't say much, but she confirmed I'm about 9 weeks along.

*[Her expression becomes more uncertain]*

The thing is, after that first visit, I haven't really gone back. They gave me information about coming back for more appointments and stuff, and they talked about prenatal vitamins and not smoking, but... 

*[She trails off, looking a bit guilty]*

I haven't made another appointment. Part of it is that it's hard to get there—no car, relying on buses or my parents. And part of it is just... I'm still so unsure about everything. Like, why start all these appointments and prenatal care if I'm not even sure I'm going to continue the pregnancy?

*[She looks up at you]*

Is that... is that bad? Should I be going more regularly?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia nods thoughtfully]*

Right now, it's just the free clinic—I think it's called the Community Health Center or something like that? It's the one over on Dempster Street. I've been there a couple times for other stuff before—like when I had that concussion last year—so I kind of knew where it was.

*[She speaks a bit more openly]*

The nurse I saw for my pregnancy confirmation was really good, actually. Her name was... I think it was Ms. Rodriguez? She was patient and didn't make me feel rushed. She explained things clearly and didn't talk down to me, which I appreciated. She asked about my living situation, my support system, whether I felt safe at home—stuff like that. It felt like she actually cared, not just like she was checking boxes.

*[Her expression becomes more hesitant]*

But here's the thing—I don't know if I'll see the same person next time, or if there even will be a next time soon. That's kind of the problem with the free clinic. It's not like I have a regular doctor who knows me and my whole situation. It's whoever's available that day. So it's hard to build like, a real relationship with someone.

*[She fidgets with her hands]*

And honestly? I've been dealing with anxiety for a while—like, untreated anxiety—and I haven't really talked to anyone at the clinic about that in relation to the pregnancy. I don't know if I should bring it up, or if they'd even be able to help with that.

*[She looks at you]*

Do you think I need to find a specific OB or something? Because I don't even know how I'd do that without insurance...

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia lets out a small, somewhat self-conscious laugh]*

Well, that's kind of the problem, isn't it? I've only had the one appointment—the initial confirmation visit at the free clinic. So I don't really have a "typical" visit yet because I haven't established a regular schedule.

*[She looks down, a bit sheepish]*

I know I'm supposed to go back. The clinic gave me paperwork that said something about coming back in like 4 weeks, and then more frequently as I get further along. But I haven't actually scheduled anything since that first visit.

*[She shifts uncomfortably]*

I guess I've been kind of... avoiding it? Which I know isn't great. It's like, part of me is still hoping that if I don't go to more appointments, I won't have to fully commit to any decision about the pregnancy. That sounds dumb when I say it out loud, but that's kind of where my head's at.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

From what I remember from that first visit, they did the ultrasound, took some blood I think, asked me a bunch of health questions. The whole thing took maybe an hour with the wait time included. But I don't really know what to expect from future appointments—like, what they'll check, how long they'll take, or if they'll keep pushing the prenatal vitamins and telling me to quit smoking.

*[She looks up at you]*

Do you think... do you think I should go ahead and schedule another appointment? I mean, even though I'm still unsure about what I want to do?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia pauses and considers the question carefully]*

Um, not like... serious complications, I don't think? But there are definitely things going on.

*[She counts on her fingers]*

So physically, I've been really nauseous—like, especially in the mornings, but sometimes all day. I'm exhausted all the time, even when I sleep a lot. My boobs are sore. And I've been having some cramping on and off, which kind of freaks me out because I don't know if that's normal or if something's wrong.

*[She looks a bit worried]*

I haven't asked anyone about the cramping yet because I didn't want to go back to the clinic unless it was like, an emergency. But now I'm wondering if I should have mentioned it.

*[She shifts in her seat]*

The other thing is... I mean, my anxiety has been really bad. Like, worse than usual. I'm constantly worried about the pregnancy, worried about what I'm going to do, worried about money, worried about my parents' reaction... it's just a lot. Some nights I can't sleep because my brain won't shut off. And I know stress isn't good for the baby, but I can't really control it.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

I'm also still smoking, which I know is bad. I've cut back a little bit, but not much. And I'm not taking the prenatal vitamins they gave me information about. I just... I haven't gotten them filled or anything.

*[She looks up at you, a bit defensively but also vulnerably]*

I also had that concussion last year that's on my record. I don't know if that matters now that I'm pregnant? Nobody's really explained that to me.

Is any of this... is this stuff I should be worried about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia shakes her head]*

Um, honestly? Nothing right now. I'm not on any medications.

*[She hesitates slightly]*

Well, I mean... I smoke, so nicotine, I guess? But that's not like, a prescribed medication or anything.

*[She looks a bit guilty]*

The clinic gave me information about prenatal vitamins—I think it was like a pamphlet or something—and they said I should start taking them, especially folic acid because of like, brain development or whatever. But I haven't actually filled that prescription or gotten them yet. It's partly because I wasn't sure if I was going to keep the pregnancy, so I was like, "why bother?" But also just because... I don't know, I've never been great at remembering to take stuff regularly.

*[She shifts uncomfortably]*

I've dealt with anxiety for a while, like I mentioned, but I've never actually been prescribed anything for that. I just kind of... deal with it. My parents suggested I talk to someone about it, but without insurance, I didn't know how to make that happen or afford it.

*[She looks at you with some concern]*

Should I be taking something for the anxiety while I'm pregnant? Like, is that safe? And like, how important is the prenatal vitamin thing really? I know it's probably important, but I'm just... I'm not really on top of things right now.

*[She pauses]*

Is there anything else I should be taking that I don't know about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia grimaces a bit and tucks her hair behind her ear]*

Okay, so... I'm not going to lie, my diet isn't great. It's probably worse now than it was before I found out I was pregnant.

*[She speaks somewhat defensively]*

Like, money is tight, so I eat what's affordable and easy. A lot of like, ramen, cereal, sandwiches, fast food when I can afford it. My parents try to have decent meals at home, but I'm not always eating with them. I grab whatever's quick.

*[She pauses, looking a bit uncomfortable]*

Since I've been pregnant, the nausea has made it even harder. Like, some days I can't really stomach much of anything except like, crackers or ginger ale. Other days I'm starving and I'll eat whatever's available. There's not really a pattern.

*[She looks down at her lap]*

I know I'm probably supposed to be eating like, really healthy stuff—vegetables and protein and all that. But honestly, I don't really know what I'm supposed to be eating specifically for pregnancy. Nobody's really gone through that with me in detail. The clinic gave me some paperwork, but it was kind of generic and didn't really account for like, my budget or what's actually available to me.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

I don't drink alcohol or anything, if that matters. And I try to drink water, but sometimes I just drink whatever's easiest—soda, juice, whatever.

*[She looks up at you]*

Is my diet something I need to like, completely overhaul? Because honestly, that feels overwhelming on top of everything else right now.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia's eyes get a bit watery, and she takes a shaky breath]*

Honestly? It's been really hard. Like, emotionally, I'm kind of all over the place.

*[She wraps her arms around herself]*

Some days I feel okay, like maybe I can handle this. And then other days I wake up and the anxiety just hits me like... I can't breathe. I'm thinking about all the ways I could mess this up, or all the reasons I'm not ready to be a mom, or what if something's wrong with the baby, or what if I can't afford to take care of it...

*[Her voice gets quieter]*

And then there's guilt, you know? Like, I feel guilty for not being more excited or grateful or whatever I'm supposed to feel. I feel guilty for smoking. I feel guilty for not going to my appointments. I feel guilty that the dad isn't around and that my parents are stressed because of me.

*[She looks up, her eyes glistening]*

I've always had anxiety—like, social anxiety, generalized anxiety—but this is different. It's like, the pregnancy has like, amplified everything. I can't sleep sometimes because my brain won't shut off. I overthink everything. I get panic-y about stupid stuff.

*[She pauses, speaking more vulnerably]*

And then there's the uncertainty about what I actually want to do. Like, am I keeping this baby? Am I adopting it out? Some days I lean one way, and other days I'm completely different. That uncertainty is like... it's exhausting, you know? I can't make a decision, so I'm just kind of stuck in limbo.

*[She looks at you]*

My mom has been supportive, but I can tell she's worried about me. And that makes me feel worse. I don't want to be a burden on her.

Is it normal to feel this way? Like, should I be talking to someone about this?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia's expression softens a bit, and she seems to relax slightly]*

Um, okay, so... my support system is kind of small, but like, the people who are there are trying.

*[She counts on her fingers]*

My mom is probably my biggest support. Like, she was upset when I told her, but not in like, a mean way. She's worried, but she's also been like, "we'll figure this out." She's offered to help with doctor's appointments, to come with me if I want. She's been asking if I need anything, checking in on how I'm feeling. She's stressed about money and everything, but she's still showing up for me.

*[She pauses]*

My dad is... quieter about it. He hasn't said a lot, but he's not like, angry or kicking me out or anything. I think he's just processing it in his own way. He's worried, I can tell.

*[She continues]*

I have a couple friends I've told. One of them, my best friend Maya, has been really supportive. She checks in on me, asks how I'm doing, listens when I need to vent. But like, she's also 19 and dealing with her own stuff, so I don't want to burden her too much with all of this.

*[Her expression becomes more uncertain]*

The dad... he's not really part of this. Like I said, he kind of disappeared when I told him. I've tried reaching out a couple times, but he doesn't really respond. So that's been hard—like, I'm doing this alone without him.

*[She looks down]*

I don't really have like, a mentor or counselor or anything. No therapist, no pregnancy counselor, no case manager. The clinic staff have been nice, but they're not like, ongoing support people, you know?

*[She looks up at you]*

I think that's part of why I'm struggling so much. Like, I have my mom and my friend, but they can only do so much. And I feel like I need someone who actually understands pregnancy and all the options and can help me think through this without judging me.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

Do you think I should try to find someone like that? A counselor or something?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia looks a bit taken aback by the question, and lets out a nervous laugh]*

Um... honestly? I haven't really thought about that yet. Like, at all.

*[She shifts uncomfortably in her seat]*

I mean, I know there are like, different ways to have a baby—hospital, natural, C-section, all that stuff. But I haven't like, researched it or thought about what I would want. Partly because I'm still not even sure if I'm going to be pregnant when the time comes, you know?

*[She speaks more hesitantly]*

Like, I know I need to make a decision about whether I'm keeping the baby or not, and I feel like that has to come before I start planning like, how I want to deliver it. Does that make sense?

*[She pauses, looking a bit defensive]*

I guess if I'm being honest, the whole idea of actually giving birth is kind of terrifying. Like, I've heard it hurts a lot, and there are complications that can happen, and... I don't know. I haven't really let myself think about it too much because it feels too real and scary.

*[She looks down at her hands]*

My mom has mentioned that the hospital she was born at is pretty good, and that I could probably go there. But that's like, the extent of my planning so far.

*[She looks up at you]*

Is this something I should be thinking about now? Or is it like, too early since I'm only 9 weeks and still figuring out what I want to do?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia thinks for a moment, then shrugs]*

Honestly? Not a lot of reliable stuff, I think.

*[She speaks somewhat sheepishly]*

Like, mostly I've just like, googled things when I get worried. Like, I'll be having cramping or feeling weird and I'll be like, "is this normal?" and I'll search it on my phone. But then I get like, a million different results—some say it's totally fine, some say it's a sign of miscarriage, and I end up more freaked out than I started.

*[She continues]*

I've looked at some pregnancy apps too. I downloaded one that like, tells you what's happening with the baby each week and what to expect. That's kind of helpful, but also sometimes it's like, too much information at once, you know?

*[She pauses]*

My mom has talked to me about some stuff from her own pregnancies, and that's been helpful. Like, she's told me what was normal for her, what to expect. But I don't know if everything she experienced will be the same for me.

*[She looks a bit guilty]*

The clinic gave me some pamphlets and information sheets when I went for my appointment, but honestly, I haven't read through all of them carefully. They're just kind of sitting on my desk at home. I think one was about prenatal vitamins, one was about nutrition, maybe one about like, what to expect during pregnancy? But I haven't really dug into them.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

I haven't like, watched videos or read books or anything formal. I don't really know where to start with that, and it feels overwhelming. Plus like, a lot of the information out there seems to assume you've already decided to have the baby, and I haven't even done that yet.

*[She looks up at you]*

Where do you think I should be getting information from? Like, reliable sources?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia's expression becomes visibly stressed, and she lets out a long sigh]*

Okay, so... this is honestly one of the biggest things stressing me out right now.

*[She speaks quickly, as if the words are tumbling out]*

Like, I don't have steady income. I've done some part-time stuff—babysitting, helping a neighbor with yard work, stuff like that—but it's not consistent. Some months I might make like, a couple hundred dollars, and other months barely anything. My parents help cover my basic needs, but they're already struggling with their own bills and mortgage and everything.

*[She wraps her arms around herself]*

I don't have insurance, right? So like, I don't even know how much all of this is going to cost. The free clinic is helping with the prenatal stuff, which is good, but what about the actual birth? What if there are complications? What if I need to go to the hospital? I've heard that can be really expensive.

*[She looks worried]*

And then if I keep the baby... like, where would I even live? I can't stay with my parents forever. Babies need like, so much stuff—cribs, car seats, formula, diapers. That's expensive. And I'd need childcare if I wanted to work or go back to school or anything.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

Honestly? That's part of why I'm so uncertain about keeping the pregnancy. Like, how am I supposed to afford to raise a baby when I can barely afford to take care of myself?

*[She pauses]*

My mom has mentioned like, WIC and food stamps and stuff like that, but I don't really know how to apply for that or if I'd even qualify. And adoption... I don't know if that costs money or what that process even looks like.

*[She looks at you, seeming overwhelmed]*

Have you... do you know about resources for people in my situation? Like, financial help or assistance programs?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia shifts in her seat, looking a bit uncomfortable]*

Well, like I said, I don't really have like, a steady job right now. So in some ways, the pregnancy hasn't like, directly affected employment because I'm not employed in the traditional sense.

*[She speaks more thoughtfully]*

But it's definitely made things harder in terms of like, finding work or being able to work. Like, the fatigue is real—some days I'm so exhausted that I can barely get out of bed. And the nausea makes it hard to focus on anything. If I had a job right now, I don't know how I'd manage.

*[She pauses]*

I was thinking about maybe picking up more babysitting gigs or something to try to make some money before the baby comes—if I'm keeping it. But honestly, I'm worried about like, the physical demands of that when I'm pregnant. And I don't know what I'm supposed to tell people. Like, do I tell them I'm pregnant? Do I hide it?

*[She speaks more quietly]*

My mom has suggested that maybe I should think about like, going back to school or getting my GED or something, but that feels impossible right now. Like, how am I supposed to focus on school when I'm dealing with all of this?

*[She looks down at her hands]*

I think once I figure out what I'm doing with the pregnancy, I'll have a better sense of what I can do work-wise. But right now, it's just kind of... on hold, I guess.

*[She looks up at you]*

Is there like, job training or employment help for pregnant people? Or am I just kind of stuck in this limbo until I make a decision?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia looks almost startled by the question, as if it hadn't really occurred to her]*

Um... postpartum? Like, after the baby is born?

*[She laughs nervously]*

Honestly, I haven't thought that far ahead. Like, I'm still trying to figure out if I'm even going to have a baby, and you're asking me about what happens after...

*[She pauses, collecting her thoughts]*

I mean, I guess if I do keep the baby, I would... stay with my parents? At least for a while? My mom has mentioned that she could help with like, the first few weeks or whatever. But I don't really have a plan beyond that.

*[She speaks more uncertainly]*

Like, I know postpartum is like, a real thing that happens. I've heard it can be hard—like, recovery and hormones and depression and stuff. But I haven't really looked into what that means or what I'd need to do to take care of myself during that time.

*[She wraps her arms around herself]*

And like, if I'm not working, how would I afford time off? And what about like, postpartum checkups? I don't even have regular prenatal care figured out, so I have no idea how that would work.

*[She looks at you with a mix of anxiety and curiosity]*

Honestly, the whole thing feels so far away and overwhelming that I kind of just... haven't let myself think about it. Is that something I should be planning for now? Like, even though I'm still unsure about the pregnancy itself?

*[She hesitates]*

What does postpartum care even involve?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*[Olivia nods, looking somewhat relieved but also thoughtful. She uncrosses her arms slightly]*

Yeah, um... thank you for listening, I guess. It was actually kind of helpful to like, talk through all of this out loud, even though it made me realize how much I don't have figured out.

*[She stands up slowly, tucking her hair behind her ear]*

I appreciate that you didn't judge me or anything. Like, I know I'm not doing everything right—I'm not going to appointments, I'm still smoking, I haven't taken the vitamins. But talking about it made me think that maybe I should... I don't know, try harder or something.

*[She pauses at the door]*

Do you think... like, is there any chance you could send me information about those resources you mentioned? Like, the financial assistance stuff, or counseling, or like, reliable pregnancy information? Because I think I need to actually start taking this seriously, whether I keep the baby or not.

*[She speaks more quietly]*

And maybe I should call the clinic and schedule another appointment. Even if I'm still unsure about what I want to do, I should probably at least get checked out and talk to someone about the anxiety and the cramping and stuff, right?

*[She looks at you with a mix of uncertainty and determination]*

Thank you again. This was... this was good. I needed this.

*[She gives a small, tired smile before heading out]*

---

**[END OF INTERVIEW]**

persona_traceability.description: Olivia is a 19-year-old student with a high school diploma living in suburban Chicago with a low income. She is single and uninsured, relying on free clinics for healthcare. Olivia is sedentary, smokes, and has untreated anxiety. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not taking prenatal vitamins.
